title: About Me
text:
Hi, I’m Raihan! I’m an international student from Indonesia who loves all things creative and tech-related, especially UI/UX. I enjoy exploring unique designs and figuring out how to make digital experiences more intuitive and fun. When I’m not checking out cool ideas, I’m probably watching football (die-hard Man United fan!), diving into manga, or admiring sleek JDM cars.
This blog is part of my Homework 3 assignment for IS 407. I’ll be sharing some interesting and reproducible data science projects that blend creativity with insights from data. Hope you enjoy following along!

title: The Relationship Between Annual Income and Car Price
text:
Dataset Source: Car Sales Report Dataset
The scatter plot below shows the relationship between Annual Income and Car Price based on data from a car sales dataset. This data gives insights into car-buying behavior, showing how income influences purchasing decisions.
One of the key insights I noticed was that those with higher income levels are linked to higher car prices. The red line within the graph confirmed this by highlighting the relationship between the two variables. While this is true for most, there are some outliers, with some individuals with low incomes purchasing more expensive cars; they are likely to do this through financing or savings. On the other hand, some high-income buyers choose to buy budget-friendly vehicles, which could reflect their priorities or preferences for the car’s practicalities instead.
From the key insights I gained, this visualization is especially useful for car dealerships and manufacturers. Understanding the relationship between income and car prices could help them target the right audience and offer products to a broader range of customers. Lastly, it would be fun to see how this relationship will grow with the rise of electric and alternative fuel vehicles. With new trends, we could see a shift in how income influences people’s choice of cars, and exploring further on this could reveal even more information on consumer behavior.

# Load necessary libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)


Attaching package: 'dplyr'


The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

    filter, lag


The following objects are masked from 'package:base':

    intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

# Load the dataset
setwd("/Users/raihanseno/Documents/UIUC/Fall 2024/IS 407/hw3_Raihana2")
car_sales_data <- read.csv("data/car_sales.csv") # Ensure file path is correct

# Check column names
colnames(car_sales_data)

 [1] "Car_id"        "Date"          "Customer.Name" "Gender"       
 [5] "Annual.Income" "Dealer_Name"   "Company"       "Model"        
 [9] "Engine"        "Transmission"  "Color"         "Price...."    
[13] "Dealer_No"     "Body.Style"    "Phone"         "Dealer_Region"

# Filter out rows with missing or invalid data
car_sales_filtered <- car_sales_data %>%
  filter(!is.na(Annual.Income) & !is.na(Price....)) 

# Convert income and price to thousands
car_sales_filtered <- car_sales_filtered %>%
  mutate(
    Annual.Income.Thousands = Annual.Income / 1000,
    Price.Thousands = Price.... / 1000
  )

# Scatter plot: Car Price vs. Annual Income in thousands
ggplot(car_sales_filtered, aes(x = Price.Thousands, y = Annual.Income.Thousands)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5, color = "blue") + # Add scatter points
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE, color = "red", linetype = "dashed") +
  labs(
    title = "Relationship Between Car Price and Annual Income",
    x = "Car Price (in thousands $)",
    y = "Annual Income (in thousands $)"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'

title: Top 10 Most Popular Categories by Total Installs
text:
Dataset Source: Google Play Store Apps Dataset
The graph below highlights the Top 10 Most Popular Categories by Total Installs on the Google Play Store. Coming at number one as the category with the total installs is gaming apps, with the category-leading the cart with over 30 billion installs; this shows the immense popularity of mobile gaming on a global scale. In second place are communication apps, such as messaging and social media apps, showing how essential their role is in helping people connect. Productivity apps hold the third position, showing how tools are designed to improve efficiency and organization.
Other categories, including social, tools, family, and photography apps, follow with moderate popularity but significantly fewer installs compared to the top three. This analysis provides valuable insights into user behavior, illustrating the types of apps that drive the most engagement on the Play Store. Through this data and visualization, developers and businesses can use this information to focus on high-demand categories or identify gaps in the market for new opportunities. This also showed the world’s current priorities in life, such as the need for entertainment, connectivity, and productivity. 
In the future, I would like to know whether there will be a change in trend, especially with the rise of AI. With the rate of AI evolution, we could see growth in other categories, such as education and health. It will be fascinating to see how it all turns out in the near future.

# libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)


Attaching package: 'dplyr'


The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

    filter, lag


The following objects are masked from 'package:base':

    intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

# The dataset
setwd("/Users/raihanseno/Documents/UIUC/Fall 2024/IS 407/hw3_Raihana2")
google_play_data <- read.csv("data/googleplaystore.csv")



# Summarizing installs by category
category_installs <- google_play_data %>%
  group_by(Category) %>%
  summarize(Total_Installs = sum(Installs, na.rm = TRUE)) %>%
  arrange(desc(Total_Installs))

# Get the top 10 categories
top_10_categories <- head(category_installs, 10)

# Convert installs to billions
top_10_categories <- top_10_categories %>%
  mutate(Total_Installs_Billions = Total_Installs / 1e9)

# Bar chart of the top 10 categories by total installs
ggplot(top_10_categories, aes(x = reorder(Category, -Total_Installs_Billions), y = Total_Installs_Billions)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", fill = "skyblue") +
  labs(
    title = "Top 10 Most Popular Categories by Total Installs",
    x = "Play Store App Category",
    y = "Total Installs (in billions)"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))

  theme_minimal() +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))
